title: Expressing Feelings & Reactions in Conversation
objectives: Learn common phrases to express basic feelings (happiness, sadness, surprise, excitement, empathy)
Respond naturally in real-life situations with emotional reactions
Gain confidence in expressing genuine feelings without hesitation
Recognize when and how to use short emotional responses in everyday conversations

activities.text: Welcome to Lesson 15: ‘Expressing Feelings & Reactions in Conversation!’ अक्सर हम simple phrases बोल लेते हैं, पर emotional reactions जैसे ‘Wow, that’s great!’ कहने में हिचकिचाते हैं. कोई बात नहीं—we’ll learn how to express happiness, sadness, surprise, and more in a natural way!

activities.title: Everyday Situations Needing Emotional Responses
activities.body:
1) Good news from a friend
2) Bad news or sad events
3) Surprising or unexpected info
4) Exciting invitations or plans

इन situations में simple reaction phrases are key!

activities.text:
Let’s learn short phrases for each feeling:

• Happiness: ‘That’s wonderful!’
• Sadness: ‘I’m sorry to hear that.’
• Surprise: ‘Really? That’s surprising!’
• Excitement: ‘That’s exciting!’
• Empathy: ‘I understand how you feel.’

कई बार छोटी English line आपकी true feelings दिखाने में काफी होती है!

vocabItems.meaning: Feeling or showing pleasure (e.g. ‘I’m so happy for you!’)
To empathize or grasp feelings (e.g. ‘I understand how you feel.’)

scenes.text:
**Scenario 1: Friend Shares Good News (Happiness)**

Friend: “I got a new job offer!”
You: “Wow, that’s wonderful! I’m so happy for you!”
Friend: “Thank you! I was nervous, but it finally worked out.”
You: “That’s great news. Let’s celebrate soon!”

**Key Learning**: Use cheerful lines: ‘That’s wonderful! I’m so happy for you!’

**Scenario 2: Friend Shares Sad News (Sadness)**

Friend: “My trip got canceled because of family emergency.”
You: “Oh no, that’s sad. I’m sorry to hear that.”
Friend: “Yeah, it’s disappointing, but what can I do?”
You: “I understand how you feel. Let me know if you need anything, okay?”

**Key Learning**: Show empathy with lines like ‘I’m sorry to hear that’ and ‘I understand how you feel.’

**Scenario 3: Someone Gives Surprising Info (Surprise)**

Classmate: “Did you know our favorite café is closing?”
You: “Really? That’s surprising! I never expected that.”
Classmate: “I know, right? They suddenly announced it today.”
You: “Wow, that’s such unexpected news.”

**Key Learning**: Surprise lines: ‘Really? That’s surprising!’ ‘Wow, I didn’t expect that!’

**Scenario 4: Friend Invites You to Exciting Event (Excitement)**

Friend: “We’re planning a weekend trip to the mountains!”
You: “That’s exciting! I can’t wait to join you guys.”
Friend: “Yes, it’ll be so much fun.”
You: “Absolutely. I’m looking forward to it!”

**Key Learning**: Express excitement with phrases like ‘That’s exciting!’ or ‘I can’t wait!’

activities.text:
Also show empathy/support phrases:
• ‘Don’t worry, it’ll be okay.’
• ‘I’m here if you need help.’

ये छोटे sentences बहुत comfort देते हैं!

scenes.userLine: Friend: ‘I just won a dance competition!’
scenes.mentorLine: You: ‘Wow, that’s awesome! I’m so proud of you!’
scenes.mentorTip: Use an enthusiastic tone—like real excitement!

scenes.mentorLine: You: ‘Oh no, that’s sad. I’m sorry it happened.’
scenes.mentorTip: Show a soft, concerned tone for sadness.

activities.text: Tone matters! Happiness = bright tone, sadness = softer tone, surprise = a bit higher pitch. एक small change in your voice can convey real feelings.

activities.question: Which emotion do you find hardest to express?

dynamicFeedback.0: Try: ‘I’m so happy for you!’ or ‘That’s wonderful!’
dynamicFeedback.1: Use: ‘I’m sorry to hear that.’ ‘Oh no!’
dynamicFeedback.4: Use: ‘I understand how you feel.’ ‘Don’t worry.’

activities.sentence: ______ (That’s exciting/I’m sad) I can’t wait to go!
hints: We’re expressing excitement, so choose the positive phrase!

feedback.wrongText: We’re not sad here—excitement is the right feeling.

activities.prompt: Say out loud: ‘Really? That’s surprising! I didn’t know that.’ (practice a surprised tone!)
Practice sadness phrase: ‘Oh no, that’s sad. I’m sorry to hear that.’ (soft tone, show concern)

scenes.text:
**Scenario 5: Showing Support & Empathy**

Friend: “I’m worried about my exams.”
You: “I understand how you feel. Don’t worry, you’ll do fine!”
Friend: “Thanks for understanding.”

**Key Learning**: Simple empathy line: ‘I understand how you feel. Don’t worry!’

activities.text: Remember: इन short phrases से आप real feelings easily express कर सकते हैं! No huge sentences needed—just 1-2 lines with the right tone is enough to connect emotionally.

activities.sentence: Wow, ______ (that’s great/oh no)! I’m so happy for you!
hints: Response to good news, so ‘that’s great’ is correct!

feedback.correctText: Exactly—‘that’s great!’ shows a positive reaction.
feedback.wrongText: ‘Oh no’ is used for sad or negative news.

activities.question: Which new phrase do you love most so far?

dynamicFeedback.0: Great for sharing in someone’s happiness!
dynamicFeedback.3: Use for big events or plans!

activities.title: Emotional Encouragement
activities.body: Feelings express करना कोई formal भाषा नहीं—just short, real lines with genuine tone. थोड़ी Hindi mix भी चलेगा. It shows you care!

activities.text: Anytime someone shares something, think: Is it good, bad, surprising, exciting, or needs support? Use these short reaction lines. Practice them daily—boldly express yourself!

activities.title: Lesson 15 Recap
activities.body:
1) Happiness: ‘That’s wonderful! I’m so happy for you!’
2) Sadness: ‘I’m sorry to hear that.’ ‘Oh no, that’s sad.’
3) Surprise: ‘Really? That’s surprising!’
4) Excitement: ‘That’s exciting!’ ‘I can’t wait!’
5) Empathy: ‘I understand how you feel.’ ‘Don’t worry!’

Short phrases, real feelings!

activities.title: Express Yourself Champion
activities.description: Congratulations! You’ve learned how to express your feelings and reactions naturally in English. Keep using these small lines and share your emotions confidently!
